description: Limit Yourself to 5 Instruments.
You are not starting a track. You are just playing around for 20 minutes. Store the result somewhere and then start something else.
Start from a bpm of 100.
Start by distorting an existing sound or sample.
Pick a painting you like. Keep that painting on a screen while you compose. Try and relate the feeling you get from the painting in music.
Write a melodic hook in 5 minutes. It doesn’t have to be good, just write it. Repeat 4 times. Start a project from the best one.
Start by writing the cheesiest / most obvious melody that comes to mind. Use it as a base for a new track. When you've added a few more elements, remove it.
Start by writing a polyrhythmic pattern, 2 sounds playing two distinctive rhythms that complement each other.
Think about a movie that moved you deeply. Start a track that reconnects you with the feeling of that movie.
Start by taking a 5mn walk in your neighbourhood. Find a track name from what you have seen in those 5mn and start working.
Today you are not trying to make a good track. You are just making a track. Allow yourself to produce an average sounding track.
Start by using a time signature you have never or rarely used before.
Use a song you like as a template. Put it in your daw and use the template's bpm and song structure as a starting point.
Use your phone or any portable recorder to record a sound or an atmosphere from your surrounding or from the street. Use this recording as the starting point of the song.
Start by gathering 10 sounds in a folder. Make a track with those 10 sounds only.
Start by building an instrument from scratch or by tweaking an existing one to create an unusual sound texture.
Today you are not writing a track. Today you are only spending time doing sound design. Either creating synth patches or sorting through and organizing samples. Set a time target and do it.
Make a loop from a song you like. Play / improvise over the top of it for 5mn. Remove the loop and use any interesting bits from what you have recorded to start a new project.
Start by writing a track structure before writing the actual parts.
Download a midi file of a song from the internet. Use a melody line or chord structure from the song. Tweak until unrecognizable and start your song from there.
Pick a situation or a subject that really annoys you. Write a protest track to that situation or subject.
Think of a music genre that you secretly love and is clearly untrendy. Start by writing in that genre.
Start by arbitrarily mixing two very different music aesthetics.
Pick a track from an album that has been trending in the last couple of months and use it as a model.
Write a track to express a feeling that was felt by a friend or a fictional character.
Don’t make a full track. Just play around for 20 minutes and don’t worry whether it’s good or not. Do it three times in a row.
Start by writing the kind of music you were into when you were 15 years old.
Start by going through the unfinished tracks on your hard drive. Pick one and revisiit it.
Start from a fully formed drum loop of an unfamiliar style. You are allowed to remove the loop only when you have added a few elements to it.
Take a book, a movie or a personal story as a starting point. The goal of the track you are writing is to tell this story.
Start by writing the most 'cliched' part a producer / songwriter could write in your favorite genre. Forget your ego.
Start by changing the normal tuning of an instrument.
Record a part, don’t worry about making mistakes. Pick one of the mistakes as the central part for a new track.
Start by streaming your music production process on social media for 30 minutes.
Pick one of your favourite artists. Imagine you are writing this track to submit it to him / her.
Start by singing a beat and writing it on your daw.
Start by finding a riff on your favourite instrument.
Start by replicating an element from a known song of rnb.
Start by replicating a bassline from a known artist whose name starts with a C.
Start by sampling a vocals loop from youtube. Use a country name as a search term. Don’t get lost clicking on all the youtube suggestions!
Start by picking a keys loop in your library.
Grab a short cut of a movie and write a soundtrack for it.
Start by using a chord progression from a song you like and change the chord order.
Start by applying an unknown technique learnt from a short tutorial.
Start by creating a physical instrument from scratch. For example, build a craft percussion, or use an acoustic instrument in a twisted way.
Start a track in another daw than your usual one. Using a different tool can help change perspective
Download the manual of a virtual synth you own and study one feature to come up with an idea.
Start with a bpm that is 30 units faster or slower that your most comfortable speed. For example if your favourite bpm is 140, try doing something at 110.
Start by picking one sample and making as many sounds from it as possible. For example, try and make drums sounds and textures out of the same sample.
Start by designing a new synth patch.
Start by borrowing a musical technique from a less-familiar genre online tutorial. For example if you are a hip-hop producer, go learn a techno-music producing technique.
Start with a drum kit made of 3 sounds only.
Start by importing a recording made on your phone.
Think of an important moment in your life from 5 to 10 years ago. Write a soundtrack for it.
Pick a track and automate 5 parameters on it.
If you have the set up for it, stand up while producing for the next hour
Write a transition between 2 sections that seem to fit well into each other
Try and invert the sections you wrote
Identify what sounds too good in the track - make it weirder
Work for 5 minutes very quickly. Repeat 3 times
Use your own vocals as a texture
Send a demo of the current state of song to a musician / producer friend. Ask him / her what he / she would do.
Incorporate some real-life noise from your direct surroundings into the track.
Make sure you have a song structure before getting into the details. Don’t lose the big picture.
Think like an engineer. Write down a list of what is left to be done in the track. Break down the problem into small chunks and apply.
Pause and take 10 minutes to study the history of one genre associated with the track you are making. Don’t get stuck in the youtube hole though. Use a timer.
Emphasize what's obvious and cliched in your track.
Add an element from a music genre that you secretly love and is clearly untrendy.
Leave a loop of the song to play in the backround and go take a shower
Sample an element of the music you have written so far. Cut it and replay it in a surprising way.
Don’t be afraid of repetition.
Convert a melodic element into a rhythmic element.
Be extravagant. Overdo what you would normally do.
Shut the door and listen from outside.
Find the bits of the track that hurt the most and emphasize how bad they sound.
Work extremely fast for 10 minutes.
Read a part of a boring book in silence for 10 minutes.
Find the most embarrassing details of your current track and amplify them.
Work for 15 minutes with half of the tracks muted.
Identify an element that is a detail of least importance. Give it more visibility, change the layering logic.
Reverse one of the elements of the track.
Remove notes from either the bassline or any other melodic line.
Humanize the parts that are quantized / programmed too precisely.
Use filters.
Add an unacceptable chord progression in the track.
Do nothing for as long as possible.
Play the song as loud as possible, stand up and listen to your body.
Tidy up
Make a sudden, destructive unpredictable action; incorporate it.
Emphasize the contrats between the different constituting elements of your track.
Change instrument roles ex : make the melody the bassline etc…
Take away the 3 first elements in order of apparent non-importance.
Emphasize repetitions.
Ask someone who isn’t a musician to suggest a melody line.
Do something that is really easy, obvious or cliched.
Stop the music. Close your eyes. Take 15 deep breathes.
Go work for an hour from a different location to your usual music writing space. Go to a café, go outdoors, work from public transport...
Duplicate a particular drum loop 10 times and try and derive 10 variations of that particular loop.

Duplicate a loop and create a new version changing some aspect of it (sound design, harmony, melody, rhythmic pattern...). Duplicate the modified loop, modify it again and repeat the whole process 5 times.
Record an existing chord or note through an unusual reverb, sample it using the tail only and use it in your composition.
Record a part by using your punch instead or single fingers on a controller. Result will sound better if you use a midi plug-in to limit the possible notes to a certain scale.
Convert ALL midi tracks into audio. Make decision, commit and move forward.
Work on a different version of a MIDI part by applying MIDI transposition, note inversion, reverse or time shifting. Try to superimpose that new part on the original.
Pick a random syllable and use it as a search argument in your sample library to find some new samples and presets.
Double one of the instruments and change the texture to add a new layer.
Create ‘odd’ loops by duplicating a loop, removing some notes and setting it to a different loop length.
Slice an ambient texture audio clip at random locations, apply a different effect to each slice.
Copy a drum MIDI pattern and paste it on a synth MIDI track.
Write a tonality change : same pattern repeats one half tone up the scale.
Layer a melody line with different textures or instruments. Create more sound color variations by balancing dynamically those layers.
Write 3 alternate voicings for the chord progression.
Write 3 alternate versions of the chord progression adding or removing notes to the chords.
Get out of the studio, spend 30mn recording random sounds on your phone then try and use them in your project.
Try and use a synth or percussion sound that you would be ashamed to use.
Work 30mn with earplugs
Write a part using noise / something that isn’t an instrument.
Imagine you are your closest friend. Try and write an element as if you were that person.
Change the BPM drastically
Use children’s voices as a sample.
Focus on one tiny element of the song for the next 30mn.
Listen in total darkness.
Don't be afraid of things because they're easy to do.
Don't be frightened of clichés.
Take the pressure off yourself and aim for good enough. Accept good enough enough times and soon it'll develop into something great.
Tune the drums to the song.
Apply subtle automation to a synth’s envelope to give a pattern more life.
Remove as many elements as possible - stick to the bare bones.
Insert unique events to break some repetitions.
Your job is not to create perfection. It is to abandon your work when you’ve done all you can currently do. Forget your ego.
